content.question: At a certain bakery, the price of each doughnut is $1.50. Let the random variable <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the number of doughnuts a typical customer purchases each day. The expected value and variance of the probability distribution of <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are 2.6 doughnuts and 3.6 <math alttext="doughnuts squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>doughnuts</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math>, respectively. Let the random variable <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the price of the doughnuts that a typical customer purchases each day. Which of the following is the standard deviation, in dollars, of the probability distribution of <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>Â ?

choices.label: <math alttext="1.5 times the square root of 3.6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.5</mn><msqrt><mrow><mn>3.6</mn></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="the square root of 1.5 times 3.6, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mn>1.5</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3.6</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="1.5 times the square root of 2.6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.5</mn><msqrt><mrow><mn>2.6</mn></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="1.5 times the square root of 3.6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.5</mn><msqrt><mrow><mn>3.6</mn></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>

unit.text: 4: Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions

topic.text: 4.8: Mean and Standard Deviation of Random Variables

skill.text: Skill 3.B: Determine parameters for probability distributions.
